titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Paul Jean Gaston Darrot Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by Staff of Manuscripts and Archives

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 09:33

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: A collection of 210 photographs and 100 stereoptican glass slides taken by Darrot during World War I in France.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Anita (Mrs. Paul) Darrot in 1969.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Access to the original glass slides are restricted. Researchers must use digital images in Manuscripts and Archives Digital Image Database (MADID).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Paul Jean Gaston Darrot Papers (MS 591). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Paul Jean Gaston Darrot was born November 8, 1892, in Paris where his higher education included studies at the Ecole Professionelle d'Art and at the Trocadero Art School. In 1912 he joined the French Army and during World War I served in the infantry, artillery and communications section of the engineers. He was assigned to maintenance of telephone lines under fire and towards the end of the war was severely gassed. The photographs in this collection were probably made while he was in the engineers.

Soon after his discharge in 1919, Darrot left France and came to the United States. In 1922 he began working for Seth Thomas Clock Company in New York. Paul Darrot died in Southbury, Connecticut, on February 14, 1958.
* Information for this biographical sketch was taken from a letter written by Anita Darrot to the Yale University Library circa 1969.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A collection of 210 photographs and 100 stereoscopic glass slides taken by Darrot during World War I in France.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: War Poster Collection, MS 671. Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status for collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

did.unittitle: Pictures dealing with artillery (anti-aircraft implacements), bombed-out villages and specific ruins, field kitchens (and supply trains), trench and bunker scenes, French field operations (by soldiers), wartime use of French railroad

French countryside scenes—peasants at work, photographs showing activities, horse mounted units, French fighter planes, movement of 75mm gun, wartime cemeteries and burial parties, wartime use of civilian vehicles, military parades

Views of French countryside, French supply trains (ammunition, wine, etc.), rest camps—ambulance and other means of transporting wounded to camps, telephone exchanges, installation of barbed wire (and other blockades), trench scenes

Hospital and staff of Soissons, French vehicles and artillery front-line action shots (1918) and aftermath, parades of French, German, and Allied prisoners, clean-up work in French villages—cleaning up bombed-out buildings and German wreckage left behind
French landmarks—famous monuments, French prisoners of war released after armistice (1918), international boundary line—France, Germany, Belgium
Stereoscopic glass slides of World War I scenes in France

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The slides depict primarily infantry warfare in France during World War 1, 1914-1918, concluding with images of the victory parade at the end of the war and the signing of the Treaty of Versailles by President Woodrow Wilson in 1919. A significant number of images depict American troops and artillery. The slides, measuring 1 3/4 inches by 4 3/4 inches, contain duplicate photographic negatives separated by a strip of clear glass on which a brief description has been handwritten in French, presumably by Darrot. Several slides bear an illegible stamp in red ink, the significance of which is unknown.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The slides are arranged in alphabetical order by topic and geographic location based on the French description written on each slide. Some slides are numbered and were presumably used by Darrot after the war as he lectured on his wartime experiences to various groups and organizations. Although the numbers are not sequential, they have been retained with the description of the individual slides.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Glass slides in this collection are too fragile to be used. Researchers must use digital images in Manuscripts and Archives Digital Image Database (MADID).

did.unittitle: Argonne, Train de matérial américain (American transport train)
Artillerie anglaise dans la Somme (English artillery in the Somme)
(illegible).....au défilé de la Victoire (at the victory parade)
Au front, Enterrement militaire (military burial at the Front)
Avion ..... (illegible) d'une autre avion (a plane [seen?] from another plane) (#989)
Avion survolant un camp de prisonniers (plane flying over a prison camp)
Camions chargés de troupes (trucks filled with troops)
Carrefour des Trois Jurés (crossroads of the three ......) (#545)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Châteaurenault was a protected cruiser of the French Navy. Recommissioned at the outbreak of World War 1, Châteaurenault patrolled the Mediterranean. She was torpedoed by the Germans and sank in December 1917.

did.unittitle: Chavonne, Construction d'un pont (construction of a bridge) (#A-124)
Cuisine sur le front américain (cuisine on the American front)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: A French village that sustained heavy damage.

did.unittitle: Enterrement d'un soldat noir américain (burial of a black American soldier)
Eparges, attaque du front, 1915 (attack at the front) (#336)
Eparges, Relevé des morts, 1915 (removal of the dead) (#90/876)
Etat major américain (American chief of staff)
Ferme navarin, Infanterie en reserve (Navarin farm, reserve infantry (#C314, 2 duplicate slides)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Navarin Farm was a position on the Champagne battlefields where heavy fighting took place in 1915 September. The French troops captured German positions here, suffering great losses.

did.unittitle: Ferme navarin, Infanterie en reserve (Navarin farm, reserve infantry) (#C314, duplicate slide)
Fort de Douaumont ...... (illegible) en état de défense (in a state of defense)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Fort Douaumont was captured by German forces in 1916 February and in October that same year was recaptured by the French.

did.unittitle: Général Pershing au défilé de la Victoire [1919 juillet 14] (#200)
Un gros obusier américain (a large American howitzer)
Guillaume II ...... (illegible) (William II, emperor of Germany) (#116)
L'heure de la soupe (soup time) (not a duplicate)
Les Italiens au défilé de la Victoire (The Italians at the victory parade)
Joffre et Millerand sur le front remettent des décorations (Joffre and Millerand at the Front giving out medals)
Laonnais, Fort de Laniscourt (fort at Laniscourt) (#31108)
Léon Gambetta .... la Côté turque ( Léon Gambetta ...... (illegible) la Turkish side) (#170)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Léon Gambetta , an armoured cruiser, was part of the French fleet based at Malta blockading the Austrian Navy in the Adriatic. On April 27, 1915, she was torpedoed by Austro-Hungarian submarine U-5 under the command of Korvettenkapitän Georg Ludwig Ritter von Trapp, patriarch of the Von Trapp Family Singers. Of the 821 men on board, only 137 survived.

did.unittitle: Maroc en colonne (Moroccan soldiers in a column)
Maroc, Ou enterre les morts (Morocca, Where the dead are buried)
Meuse, Cuisine sous bois, 1918 (cooking under trees)
Meuse, Un P. C. américain, 1918 (An American pay clerk?)
Meuse, Pendant l'avance américain, 1918 (During the American advance)
Meuse, Transport d'un blessé américain, 1918 (Transport of a wounded American)
Mouvement américain à Château Thierry (American movement at Château Thierry)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Battle of Château-Thierry was fought From June 3-July 18, 1918, and was one of the first actions of the American Expeditionary Force (AEF) under General John J. "Black Jack" Pershing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Nieuport, later Nieuport-Delage, was a French airplane company that primarily built racing aircraft before World War I and fighter aircraft during the war.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The American Legion was founded in 1919 by veterans who served in the American Expeditionary Forces (A.E.F.) in France during World War I. Members convened in Paris in March 1919, the same year the organization was chartered by Congress.

did.unittitle: Paris, Fêtes de la Victoire, Drapeaux américains (Celebration of the victory, American flags)
Le repos près des faisceaux (Rest near the stack of weapons)
Souain, Cadavres de Goumiers (Bodies of Goumiers) (#205)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Moroccan Goumiers were soldiers who served in auxiliary units attached to the French Army of Africa, between 1908 and 1956.

did.unittitle: La soupe au camp (meal at camp)
St. Nazaire, Arrivée des troupes américains (Arrival of the American troops)
St. Rémy, Meuse, Génie américain (American engineering)
Tombe de Quentin Roosevelt (Tomb of Quentin Roosevelt) (#187)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Quentin Roosevelt was the youngest son of President Theodore Roosevelt. He joined the United States Army Air Service where he became a pursuit pilot during World War I. He died in aerial combat over France on Bastille Day, 1918 July 14.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: More than 200,000 Gurkhas (India) served in the British Army during World War I, arriving in France in 1914.

did.unittitle: Verdun, Poste de secours allemand (German aid station) (#108)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Tranchée des Baionnettes is the oldest memorial on the battle fields at Verdun.

did.unittitle: La Victoire, Défilé armée américain (Victory, American army marching)
Wilson rend visite au roi des Belges (Wilson visits the king of the Belgians)
Wilson signant le Traité de Versailles (Wilson signing the Treaty of Versailles) (#9)
